text: foreign
I've been hearing a lot about Amazon
elastic map reduce
I hear you can use it to process and
gain insights from large amounts of data
you can Amazon elastic map reduce gives
you the ability to process or Warehouse
large amounts of data without the need
to buy or manage Hardware it gives you
the ability to easily launch scale and
manage Apache Hadoop clusters on Amazon
web services and you can quickly
leverage the large ecosystem of tools
and applications in the Hadoop ecosystem
so how does it work
Amazon EMR provides a managed framework
to easily create customize and use
Hadoop clusters created with Amazon
elastic compute Cloud instances Amazon
EMR also has tight integration with
other Amazon web services like Amazon
simple storage service where you can
store both input and output data for
your Amazon EMR cluster
guess I should learn more about Amazon
ec2 and Amazon S3 well Amazon EMR takes
much of the complexity out of managing
your own cluster of Amazon ec2 instances
but if you would still like to learn
more about these Services there is free
introductory training on YouTube with a
free self-paced lap do I need to worry
about setting up Hardware or installing
running and tuning Hadoop no Amazon EMR
takes care of that so you can focus on
the analysis of your data instead of
managing your infrastructure and
software can I add more nodes to my
cluster if I want to process larger
volumes of data yes you can easily
expand or shrink your cluster by adding
or removing Amazon ec2 nodes to match
the size of your cluster with your
current needs and if you store data in
Amazon S3 it can be accessed by multiple
Amazon EMR clusters to run separate
workloads simultaneously
very cool so this means you can quickly
set up as many clusters as you need to
test new ideas and then terminate the
Clusters when you no longer need them
exactly this helps you speed up
Innovation and lower the cost of
experimentation plus you only pay for
what you use besides mapreduce what
other applications can I run on my
Amazon EMR cluster it is easy to use a
variety of powerful programs in the
Hadoop ecosystem on your cluster like
Apache Hive and pig which use higher
level languages like Hive ql SQL and pig
latin to create mapreduce jobs making it
simpler to submit jobs and queries AWS
even provides code samples and tutorials
to help how do I access Amazon EMR you
can access Amazon EMR via the AWS
Management console command line or SDK
for the AWS Management console let me
log into my account and show you what it
looks like and how easy it is to create
launch and monitor a cluster
at the AWS Management console homepage
click the Amazon S3 icon to store the
input into the cluster and to receive
the output from the cluster you can also
optionally use the Amazon S3 bucket to
backup the Hadoop log files generated by
the cluster so you can inspect them
after the cluster ends
click create bucket
enter a unique bucket name
and select a region
to avoid paying cross region bandwidth
charges create the Amazon S3 bucket in
the same region as the cluster you'll
launch in launch the cluster
click create
for this demo we will need two folders
inside this bucket
one for output
one for logs
the next step is to launch the cluster
when you do Amazon EMR Provisions Amazon
ec2 instances virtual servers to perform
the computation these Amazon ec2
instances are pre-loaded with an Amazon
machine image that has been customized
for Amazon EMR and is pre-loaded with
Hadoop and other big data applications
go back to the AWS Management console
home
and open Amazon elastic map Reduce by
clicking on the icon
click create cluster
on the create cluster page click
configure sample application
the configure sample application dialog
box opens up
choose word count from the select sample
application drop down menu
in the output location field type the
path of an Amazon S3 bucket to store
your output
leave the logging option selected
and add your new bucket and log file as
shown below
deselect the debugging option
click ok to move on and go back to the
cluster configuration page
on the cluster configuration section add
a cluster name this is optional and it
doesn't need to be unique
if not already selected choose yes to
enable termination protection which
ensures that the cluster does not shut
down due to accident or error if not
already selected choose enabled for
logging to determine whether Amazon EMR
captures detailed log data to Amazon S3
keep the rest of the cluster
configuration at default settings
under tags for the key column type owner
for the value column type development
in the software configuration section
choose Amazon to determine which
distribution of Hadoop to run on your
cluster you can choose to run the Amazon
distribution of Hadoop or one of several
map R distributions
choose 2.4.2 Hadoop 1.0.3 for the Ami
version this determines the version of
Hadoop and other applications such as
Hive or pig to run on your cluster
in the hardware configuration section
leave the network in VPC this is the
virtual private cloud
we will not be creating a new Amazon ec2
subnet so leave that option set to no
preference
for master choose M1 small the master
node assigns Hadoop tasks to core and
task nodes and monitors their status
there's always one master node in each
cluster
for this demo we are going to leave the
request spot instances box unchecked
choose M1 small for core a core node is
an Amazon ec2 instance that runs Hadoop
map and reduce tasks in stores data
using the Hadoop distributed file system
hdfs core nodes are managed by the
masternode
for the count and again leave the
request spot instance box unchecked
tasks should be M1 small and count
should be zero
keep the last request spot instances box
unchecked
for the purpose of this demo we will
leave the security and access section
values as is it is a best practice to
choose an Amazon ec2 key pair from the
list if you do not enter a value in this
field you cannot use SSH to connect to
the master node in the bootstrap actions
section there are no bootstrap actions
necessary for this sample configuration
in the steps section note the step that
Amazon EMR configured for you by
choosing the sample application you can
modify these settings to meet your needs
review your configuration and if you are
satisfied with the settings click create
cluster
when the cluster starts you see the
cluster Details page very cool next
Amazon EMR begins to count the words in
the text of the CIA World Factbook which
is pre-configured in an Amazon S3 bucket
as the input data when the cluster is
finished processing the data Amazon EMR
copies the word count results into the
output Amazon S3 bucket that you chose
in the previous steps let's take a look
at the cluster Details page while the
job is running in this example the
cluster is performing the work defined
by the word count application
expand the monitoring section to see
metrics about the cluster
these metrics are also reported to
Amazon cloudwatch and can also be viewed
from the cloud watch console the chart
Tracks number of jobs the cluster is
running status of each node in the
cluster to name a few
in the steps section you can see details
about each step in the cluster
after the cluster is complete the
results of the word frequency count are
stored in the folder you specified on
Amazon S3 when you launched the cluster
from the Amazon S3 console select the
bucket you created
you will see a success file once a
folder or object is selected you can
click actions or do a right click to
open download and delete that item
congratulations you have successfully
deployed an Amazon elastic mapreduce
cluster and processed some data thanks
now I want to get started with the free
training go to
run.quicklabs.com to try it out with a
free self-paced lab while you're there
check out the other free AWS
introduction trainings to learn about
more AWS products and services you can
play around without having to open an
account
